title: Joan Whitney Kramer
text:
Joan Whitney Kramer (June 26, 1914 – July 12, 1990) was an American <a href="singing">singer</a> and <a href="songwriter">songwriter</a>.
Early years.
Kramer was born Zoe Parenteau in <a href="Pittsburgh%2C%20Pennsylvania">Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania</a>. Her early music training came while singing in the choir in her church. She attended <a href="Finch%20College">Finch College</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
Career.
In 1934, while playing a showgirl in "<a href="The%20Great%20Waltz">The Great Waltz</a>" on <a href="Broadway%20theater">Broadway</a>, she took the <a href="stage%20name">stage name</a> Joan Whitney. She studied voice under <a href="Alex%20Kramer%20%28songwriter%29">Alex Kramer</a>, who later collaborated with her on a number of songs including "<a href="Candy%20%281944%20song%29">Candy</a>", <a href="Ain%27t%20Nobody%20Here%20but%20Us%20Chickens">Ain't Nobody Here but Us Chickens</a>, and "<a href="Far%20Away%20Places">Far Away Places</a>". Kramer and Whitney married and had a son, Doren, while living in <a href="Forest%20Hills%2C%20New%20York">Forest Hills, New York</a>.
Death.
Joan Whitney died on July 12, 1990 in <a href="Westport%2C%20Connecticut">Westport, Connecticut</a>, aged 76, from <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's disease</a>.
